Author: Abhomadi Malfegeyr
Alternative.Name: Abu  ‘Abd Allah Muhammad ibn Mu'idh
Title: Liber de crepusculis (Liber de crepusculis et nubium ascenscionibus)
Universal.Incipit: Ostendere (Ostendam) quid sit crepusculum et que causa
Manuscript: *Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS Lat. 16648
Edition1: Pedro Nunes, De crepusculis liber unus ... Item Alllacen ... de causis crepuscolorum  liber unus ... (Lisbon, 1542)
Edition2: Albasen and Witelo, Opticae thesaurus (Basel, 1572), pp. 283-88
Edition3: Pedro Nunes, De arte atque, ratione navigandi Iibri duo ... Cum Iibello Allacen de causis crepuscolorum (Coimbra, 1573)
Edition4: Pedro Nunes, Opera ... Cum libello Allacen de causis crepusculorum (Basel, 1590; facsimile reprint of 1542 ed. in G. Hellmann, Meteorologische Optik 1000-1636 (Neudrucke.. von Schriften und Karteni über Meteorologie und Erdmagnetismus, no 14 (Berlin, 1902, 87–104; reprint of 1573 ed. in Pedro Nunes, Obras, vol. 2 (Lisbon. 1945), 139–43.
Literature: A. I . Sabra, "The Authorship of the Liber de crepusculis, an Eleventh-Century Work on At­mospheric Refraction”, Isis 58 (1967), 77–85; Annotations to the 1573 edition of the text by Joaquim de Carvalho, in Pedro Nunes, Obras, vol. 2 , Lisbon 1943, 365–375.
Notes: This work has frequently been attributed to Alhazen .
Manuscript.Catalogue: L. Delisle, Inventaire des manuscrits latins conservés à la Bibliothèque impériale sous les nos 15176-16718 du fonds latin, Paris 1870 (Nachdruck Hildesheim 1974), 72

Manuscript: Roma, Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale, MS 2548 (Gesuiticus 419/H. C. 93)
Edition1: Pedro Nunes, De crepusculis liber unus ... Item Alllacen ... de causis crepuscolorum  liber unus ... (Lisbon, 1542)
Edition2: Albasen and Witelo, Opticae thesaurus (Basel, 1572), pp. 283-104
Edition3: Pedro Nunes, De arte atque, ratione navigandi Iibri duo ... Cum Iibello Allacen de causis crepuscolorum (Coimbra, 1573)
Edition4: Pedro Nunes, Opera ... Cum libello Allacen de causis crepusculorum (Basel, 1590; facsimile reprint of 1542 ed. in G. Hellmann, Meteorologische Optik 1000-1636 (Neudrucke.. von Schriften und Karteni über Meteorologie und Erdmagnetismus, no 14 (Berlin, 1902, pp. 87-104; reprint of 1573 ed. in Pedro Nunes, Obras, vol. 2 (Lisbon. 1945), pp. 139-43.

Author: Alcoati
Title: Libre de la figura del uyl
Universal.Incipit: In nomine domini nostri Ihesu Christi .. A quest libre parla de la figura del uyl e diu quines teles ...
Manuscript: *Saragossa, Biblioteca Capitular de La Seo y del Pilar, MS 1265
Edition1: Alcoati, Libre de la figura del uyl, text Catala traduit de l’Arab per Mestre Joan Jacme, ed. Lluis Deztany and Josep M. Simon de Guilleuma (Barcelona, 1933), fols. 1r-20v (pp. 41-220).
Notes: This is a Catalan translation of the work of Alcoati. It has been much debated whether the original language of composition was Latin or Arabic. However, if Deztany and Simon de Guilleuma are correct in claiming that Joan Jacme (Johannes Jacobi) translated this version of it from Arabic to Catalan, this would clearly tip the scales in favor of Arabic as the original language; the mind boggles at the thought of the work having been translated from Latin to Arabic to Catalan.

Author: Alcoati
Title: Congregatio sive liber de oculis (De egritudinibus oculorum)
Universal.Incipit: Tractatus primus de occasionibus propter quas Alcoati compilavit hunc librum ...
Manuscript: Erfurt, Universitäts- und Forschungsbibliothek, MS Ampl. F.270
Edition1: J. L. Pagel, Neue litterarische Beitrage zur mittelalterlichen Medicin, Berlin 1896, 121–194 (Tract. 1–3).
Edition2: Pagel, Die Augenheilkunde des Alcoatim, Berlin 1896?, 1–57 (Tract. 4–5).
Edition3: P. Pansier, Collectio Ophthalmologica Veterum Auctorum, fasc. 2, Paris1903, 65–179.
Literature: J. Hirschberg, "Geschichte der Augenheilkunde im Mittelalter und in der Neuzeit", in T. Author: Anonymous
Title: Speculi almukesi compositio (De speculis comburentibus)
Universal.Incipit: Quia universos (universorum/diversorum) quos de speculis ...
Manuscript: Firenze, Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana, MS Ashburnham 957
Edition1: Cl. Ptolemae Pelusiensis mathematic operis quadripartiti ... Item, de sectione conica, orthogona, quae parabola dicitur: Deque speculo ustorio, libelli duo, hactenus desiderati, ed. Antonius Gogava (Louvain, 1548), fols. 60v-70r;
Edition2: J. L. Heiberg and Eilhard Wiedemann, “Eine arabische Schrift über die Parabel und parabolische Hohlspiegel,” Bibliotheca Mathematica, Ser. 3, vol. 11 (1910-1911), pp. 193-208.
Literature: L. Thorndike, A History of Magic and Experimental Science 4, New York 1934, 177–178.
Notes: Comments: This treatise, which is perhaps more mathematical than optical, is a Latin compilation from Arabic sources. Witelo’s Perspectiva is also cited, which dates the compilation to the period after 1270. Thorndike has suggested Giovanni da Fontana as the author, but on weak grounds. The Florence MS attributes it to Roger Bacon, and (in view of the fact that Bacon did not die until 1292) this is a possibility. The London MS was improperly arranged when the codex was reconstructed after the fire of 1731; the proper order of folios is 233, 234, 231, 232; the codex was so badly mutilated that it is impossible to be certain whether fols. 230v and 235r ought to be included. The London MS is not a copy of Alhazen’s De speculis comburentibus, as has been suggested. The Vienna copy was owned by Regiomontanus.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Fondo Ashburnham Catalogo

Author: Anonymous
Title: Speculi almukesi compositio (De speculis comburentibus)
Universal.Incipit: Quia universos (universorum/diversorum) quos de speculis ...
Manuscript: London, British Museum, MS Cotton Tiberius B.IX
Edition1: Cl. Ptolemae Pelusiensis mathematic operis quadripartiti ... Item, de sectione conica, orthogona, quae parabola dicitur: Deque speculo ustorio, libelli duo, hactenus desiderati, ed. Antonius Gogava (Louvain, 1548), fols. 60v-70r;
Edition2: J. L. Heiberg and Eilhard Wiedemann, “Eine arabische Schrift über die Parabel und parabolische Hohlspiegel,” Bibliotheca Mathematica, Ser. 3, vol. 11 (1910-1911), pp. 193-208.
Literature: L. Thorndike, A History of Magic and Experimental Science 4, New York 1934, 177–178.
Notes: Comments: This treatise, which is perhaps more mathematical than optical, is a Latin compilation from Arabic sources. Witelo’s Perspectiva is also cited, which dates the compilation to the period after 1270. Thorndike has suggested Giovanni da Fontana as the author, but on weak grounds. The Florence MS attributes it to Roger Bacon, and (in view of the fact that Bacon did not die until 1292) this is a possibility. The London MS was improperly arranged when the codex was reconstructed after the fire of 1731; the proper order of folios is 233, 234, 231, 232; the codex was so badly mutilated that it is impossible to be certain whether fols. 230v and 235r ought to be included. The London MS is not a copy of Alhazen’s De speculis comburentibus, as has been suggested. The Vienna copy was owned by Regiomontanus.
Manuscript.Catalogue: A catalogue of the manuscripts in the Cottonian Library deposited in the British Museum (1802)

Author: Anonymous
Title: Speculi almukesi compositio (De speculis comburentibus)
Universal.Incipit: Quia universos (universorum/diversorum) quos de speculis ...
Manuscript: Verona, Biblioteca Capitolare, MS 206
Edition1: Cl. Ptolemae Pelusiensis mathematic operis quadripartiti ... Item, de sectione conica, orthogona, quae parabola dicitur: Deque speculo ustorio, libelli duo, hactenus desiderati, ed. Antonius Gogava (Louvain, 1548), fols. 60v-70r;
Edition2: J. L. Heiberg and Eilhard Wiedemann, “Eine arabische Schrift über die Parabel und parabolische Hohlspiegel,” Bibliotheca Mathematica, Ser. 3, vol. 11 (1910-1911), pp. 193-208.
Literature: L. Thorndike, A History of Magic and Experimental Science 4, New York 1934, 177–178.
Notes: Comments: This treatise, which is perhaps more mathematical than optical, is a Latin compilation from Arabic sources. Witelo’s Perspectiva is also cited, which dates the compilation to the period after 1270. Thorndike has suggested Giovanni da Fontana as the author, but on weak grounds. The Florence MS attributes it to Roger Bacon, and (in view of the fact that Bacon did not die until 1292) this is a possibility. The London MS was improperly arranged when the codex was reconstructed after the fire of 1731; the proper order of folios is 233, 234, 231, 232; the codex was so badly mutilated that it is impossible to be certain whether fols. 230v and 235r ought to be included. The London MS is not a copy of Alhazen’s De speculis comburentibus, as has been suggested. The Vienna copy was owned by Regiomontanus.

Universal.Incipit: Tractatus perspective habens tres partes ...
Manuscript: London, British Museum, MS Sloane 2542
Note: Lacks beginning; begins “percipi quodam modo ideo(?) non dicuntur(?) visibiles nec sensibiles ...”
Edition1: Rogerii Bacconis Perspectiva, Ed. Combach (Frankfurt, 1614), 1–167.
Edition2: Opus maius ed. Jebb (London, 1783), pp. 256-357
Edition3: Opus maius (Venice, 1750)
Edition4: The Opus Majus of Roger Bacon, ed. John Henry Bridges (London, 1900), vol. 2, pp. 1-166
Edition5: reprint of Part I of Bridges’ text (Turin, 1967)
Edition6: R. B. Burke, The Opus Majus of Roger Bacon, Philadelphia 1928, 419–582.
Edition7: D. C. Lindberg in Grant, Source Book.
Literature: E. Wiedemann, “Roger Bacon und seine Verdienste um die Opuk”, in A. G. Little (ed.), Roger Bacon Essays, London 1914, 185–203; S. Vogl, “Roger Bacons Lehre von der sinnlichen Spezies und vom Sehvorgange”, in A. G. Little (ed.), Roger Bacon Essays, London 1914, 205–27; A. G. Little, “Roger Bacon’s Works”, in A. G. Little (ed.), Roger Bacon Essays, London 1914, 379,382–384; A. C. Crombie, Robert Grosseteste and the Origin of Experimental Science 1100–1700, Oxford 1953, 144–162; D.C. Lindberg, “Alhazen’s Theory of Vision and Its Reception in the West”, Isis 58 (1967), 330–341;  A. C. Crombie, “ The Mechanistic Hypothesis and the Scientific Study of Vision: Some Optical Ideas as a Background to the Invention of the Microscope”, in S. Bradbury - G. L. 'E. Turner (eds.), Historical Aspects of Microscopy, Cambridge 1967, 27–30.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Ayscough, A Catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the British Museum (1782) 379, 405.

Author: Bacon, Roger
Title: De multiplicatione specierum (De generatione specierum / De radiis)
Universal.Incipit: Postquam habitum est de principiis rerum naturalium ...
Manuscript: Milan, Biblioteca Ambrosiana, MS R.47 sup.
Edition1: Fratris Rogeri Bacon, Ordinis Minorum, Opus Majus ad Clementum quartum, ed. Samuel Jebb (London, 1733), 358–445.
Edition2: Fratris Rogeri Bacon, Ordinis Minorum, Opus Majus ad Clementum quartum, ed. Samuel Jebb (Venice, 1750)
Edition3: The Opus Majus of Roger Bacon, ed. John Henry Bridges (London, 1900), vol. 2, pp. 405-552
Edition4: D. C. Lindberg, in Grant, Source Book.
Literature: S. Vogl, “Roger Bacons Lehre von der sinnlichen Spezies und vom Sehvorgange”, in A.G. Little (ed.), Roger Bacon Essays, London 1914, 205–227; A. G. Little, “Roger Bacon’s Works”, in A.G. Little (ed.), Roger Bacon Essays, London 1914, 386–388; D.C. Lindberg, “The Cause of Refraction in Medieval Optics”, British Journal for the History of Science 4 (1968–1969), 30–38; D.C. Lindberg, “Lines of Influenceof Therteenth-Century Optics: Bacon, Witelo, and Pecham”, Speculum 46 (1971), 67–72.
Notes: The manuscript tradition of De multiplicatione specerum is exceedingly confused, as the multiple incipit indicates. The Magdalene College (Cambridge), Erfurt, and Vienna MSS contain a fragment (incipit 5) that has sometimes been attributed to John Baconthorpe. The various families of manuscripts have been helpfully discussed by Little (ref. above).
Manuscript.Catalogue: Revelli # 330, Rivolta # 122, Gabriel (1968) 333-4

Author: Bacon, Roger
Title: De scientia experimentali (Opus maius, Part VI)
Universal.Incipit: Positis radicibus sapience latinorum penes linguas ...
Manuscript: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Digby 235
Edition1: Opus maius ed. Jebb (London, 1783), pp. 445-77
Edition2: Opus maius (Venice, 1750)
Edition3: The Opus Majus of Roger Bacon, ed. John Henry Bridges (London, 1900), vol. 2, pp. 405-578
Literature: C. B. Boyer, The Rainbow: From Myth to Mathematics, New York 1959, 99–102; A. C. Crombie, Robert Grosseteste and the Origin of Experimental Science 1100–1700, Oxford 1953, 155–162; D. C. Lindberg, “Roger Bacon’s Theory of the Rainbow: Progress or Regress?”, Isis 57 (1966), 235–248.
Notes: This work is devoted principally to thé rainbow and halo. Many of the MSS alleged to contain this treatise in fact contain only a nonoptical fragment or else an excerpt from Bacon’s Opus minus on the prolongation of life (incipit: “Corpora vero Ade et Eve post peccatum ...”).
Manuscript.Catalogue: A catalogue of Western manuscripts at the Bodleian Libraries and selected Oxford colleges

Author: Bacon, Roger

Universal.Incipit: Positis radicibus sapience latinorum penes linguas ...
Manuscript: Vatican, Biblioteca Apostolica, MS Vat. Lat. 4091
Note: Incomplete; includes some paraphrase and extracts from other treatises.
Edition1: Opus maius ed. Jebb (London, 1783), pp. 445-77
Edition2: Opus maius (Venice, 1750)
Edition3: The Opus Majus of Roger Bacon, ed. John Henry Bridges (London, 1900), vol. 2, pp. 405-578
Literature: C. B. Boyer, The Rainbow: From Myth to Mathematics, New York 1959, 99–102; A. C. Crombie, Robert Grosseteste and the Origin of Experimental Science 1100–1700, Oxford 1953, 155–162; D. C. Lindberg, “Roger Bacon’s Theory of the Rainbow: Progress or Regress?”, Isis 57 (1966), 235–248.
Notes: This work is devoted principally to thé rainbow and halo. Many of the MSS alleged to contain this treatise in fact contain only a nonoptical fragment or else an excerpt from Bacon’s Opus minus on the prolongation of life (incipit: “Corpora vero Ade et Eve post peccatum ...”).
Manuscript.Catalogue: Digital Vatican Library, Manuscripts List

Manuscript: Venice, Biblioteca Nazionale Marciana, MS Lat. VI.133 (Valentinelli XI.10)
Edition1: Fratris Rogeri Bacon, Ordinis Minorum, Opus Majus ad Clementum quartum, ed. Samuel Jebb (London, 1733), 358–445.
Edition2: Fratris Rogeri Bacon, Ordinis Minorum, Opus Majus ad Clementum quartum, ed. Samuel Jebb (Venice, 1750)

Literature: S. Vogl, “Roger Bacons Lehre von der sinnlichen Spezies und vom Sehvorgange”, in A.G. Little (ed.), Roger Bacon Essays, London 1914, 205–227; A. G. Little, “Roger Bacon’s Works”, in A.G. Little (ed.), Roger Bacon Essays, London 1914, 386–388; D.C. Lindberg, “The Cause of Refraction in Medieval Optics”, British Journal for the History of Science 4 (1968–1969), 30–38; D.C. Lindberg, “Lines of Influenceof Therteenth-Century Optics: Bacon, Witelo, and Pecham”, Speculum 46 (1971), 67–72.
Notes: The manuscript tradition of De multiplicatione specerum is exceedingly confused, as the multiple incipit indicates. The Magdalene College (Cambridge), Erfurt, and Vienna MSS contain a fragment (incipit 5) that has sometimes been attributed to John Baconthorpe. The various families of manuscripts have been helpfully discussed by Little (ref. above).

Author: Constantinus Africanus
Title: De oculis (De morbis oculorum)
Universal.Incipit: Oportet medicum oculorum curam habere (scire) volentem prius
Manuscript: Bern, Burgerbibliothek, MS 216
Edition1: Omnia opera Ysaac (Lyon, 1515), Part II, fols. 172r-178r
Edition2: the nine Juntine editions of Galen’s works, 1541-1625, as Galen, De oculis a Demetrio translatus (vol. 5, fols. 178r-187r, in the edition of 1541)
Edition3: P. Pansier, Collectio Ophthalmologica Veterum Auctorum, fasc. 7, Paris 1933, 163–208.
Edition4: The Arabic text from which this was translated, accompanied by an English translation, is available in Max Meyerhof, The Book of the Ten Treatises on the Eye ascribed to Hunain ibn Is-hag (809-877 A.D.) (Cairo, 1928)
Edition5: M. Meyerhof - C. Prifer, “Die Augenanatomie des Hunain b. Ishaq”, Sudhoffs Archiv für Geschichte der Medizin und der Naturwissenschaften 4 (1910), 163–190.
Edition6: M. Meyerhof and C. Prifer, “Die Lehre vom Sehen bei Hunain b. Ishaq”, Sudhoffs Archiv für Geschichte der Medizin und der Naturwissenschaften 6 (1913), 21–33.
Literature: J. Hirschberg, “Ober das ältesten arabischen Lehrbuch der Augenheilkunde”, Sitzungsberichte der königlich preussischen Akademie der Wissenschaften 49 (1909), 1087–1091; J. Hirschberg, "Geschichte der Augenheilkunde im Mittelalter und in der Neuzeit", in T. Saemisch (ed.), Graefe-Saemisch Handbuch der gesamten Augenheilkunde, 2nd ed., vol. 13, Leipzig 1908, 34–36; M. Meyerhof, introduction to The Book of the Ten Treatises on the Eye ascribed to Hunain ibn Is-haq (809–877 A.D.), Cairo 1928, xxii–liii; P. Pansier, Collectio Ophthalmologica Veterum Auctorum, fasc.2 (Paris, 1903), 46–49; fasc. 7 (Paris, 1938), 168–166; G. F. Vescovini, Studi sulla prospettiva medievale, Turin 1965, 106–112.
Notes: The MSS universally attribute this treatise either to Galen or to Constantinus Africanus; actually, it is Constantinus’ translation of The Ten Treatises on the Eye by Hunain ibn Ishaq (d. 877), known in the West as Johannitius. I have assigned De oculis to Constantinus in the present catalogue for the simple reason that this was the most common medieval attribution. Hirschberg and Pansier have disputed whether the work was translated from Arabic to Latin once or twice; a study of the MSS reveals two different traditions (the Bern, Paris, and Oxford, Magdalen College, MSS containing a revised or augmented version), which nevertheless appear to be based on a single translation.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Hermann Hagen, Catalogus codicum Bernensium (Bibliotheca Bongarsiana), Bern 1875, p. 262.

Author: David Armenicus
Title: De curationibus oculorum (De oculis/Liber pro sanitate oculorum)
Manuscript: *Fusignano, Biblioteca comunale Carlo Piancastelli
Note: Formerly Rome, Lib. of Prince Baldassarre Boncompagni, MS 507. Fragment from Bks. IV-VI, beginning Recipe anzeroti cocti in suco pomi cotonii florum
Edition1: Cyrurgia Guidonis de Cauliaco ... Canamusali de baldac de oculis (Venice, 1499), fols. 263r-270r
Edition2: Cyrurgia parva Guidonis ... Tractatus de oculis Canamusali (Venice, 1500), Pt. II, fols. 18r-26r;
Edition3: G. Albertotti, “Il libro delle affezioni oculari di Jacopo Palmerio da Cingoli ed altri scritti di oculistica tratti da un codice del secolo XV di Marco Sinzanogio da Sarnano,” Memon della Regia Accademia (Modena), Ser. 3, vol. 6 (1906), 61–80 (from the Fusignano MS).
Literature: M. Steinschneider, “Zur Oculistik des ‘Isa ben Ali (9 Jahrh.) und des sogenannten Canamusali,” Janus 11 (1906), 406–408; N. Scalinci, Il “Liber pro sanitate oculorum’’ di M. Davide Armenio oculista salernitano del secolo XII (Noto come ‘Tractatus de oculis Canamosali’), Naples 1934.
Notes: Traditionally attributed to Canamusali or Accanamusali (Abu-l-Qasim ‘Ammar ibn ‘Ali al-Mawsili, fl. 996-1020), this treatise is actually a compilation by David Armenicus from a variety of ancient and medieval sources.

Author: Euclid
Title: De speculis
Universal.Incipit: Visum rectum esse cuius media terminos ...
Manuscript: *Escorial, Real Biblioteca del Monasterio de San Lorenzo, MS N. II. 26
Edition1: There have been many Latin editions of Euclid’s Catroptrica, but I am not aware that any contain the medieval translation. The editions are listed by Pietro Riccardi, Saggio di una bibliografia Euclidea, 5 pts. (Bologna, 1887-1893), and by Ver Eecke, pp. xxxvi-xlvii. The latter : work contains a French translation of the Greek text.
Edition2: P. Ver Eecke, L'Optique et la Catoptrique. Avec une introduction et des notes, Brugge 1938, xxxvi–xlvii.
Literature: J. L. Heiberg, Litterargeschichtliche Studien über Euklid, Leipzig 1882, 148–153; Heiberg’s Prolegomena to Euclidis Opera omnia, ed. J. L. Heiberg and H. Menge, vol. 7 (Leipzig, 1895), xliii–lv; A. Lejeune, “Les ‘Postulats’ de la Catoptrique dite d’Euclide,” Archives internationales d’histoire des sciences 2 (1949), 598–613; A. Lejeune, Recherches sur la catoptrique grecque, Brussels 1957, 112–136.
Notes: The Greek work from which De speculis was translated is now generally agreed to be a late recension of a genuine Euclidean work, possibly edited by Theon of Alexandria. In some MSS it is attributed to Jordanus de Nemore. This De speculis must be distinguished from an Arabic compilation, also translated into Latin as Euclid’s De speculis; on the latter work, see Pseudo-Euclid (80), below.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Antolín, Guillermo, Catálogo de los códices latinos de la Real biblioteca del Escorial, Vol. 3, 1910, 146

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 1)
Universal.Incipit: Ponatur ab oculo eductas rectas lineas ferri spatio ...” Prop. I: “Nullum visorum simul videtur totum. Esto autem : visum quidem AD oculus vero B a quo incidant visus BA BG BK BD ...
Manuscript: †Erfurt, Universitäts- und Forschungsbibliothek, MS Ampl. Q.385
Edition1: There have been many Latin editions of Euclid’s Catroptrica, but I am not aware that any contain the medieval translation. The editions are listed by Pietro Riccardi, Saggio di una bibliografia Euclidea, 5 pts. (Bologna, 1887-1893), and by Ver Eecke, pp. xxxvi-xlvii. The latter : work contains a French translation of the Greek text.
Edition2: P. Ver Eecke, L'Optique et la Catoptrique. Avec une introduction et des notes, Brugge 1938, xxxvi–xlvii.
Literature: J. L. Heiberg, Litterargeschichtliche Studien über Euklid, Leipzig 1882, 90–148; H. Weissenborn, “Zur Optik des Eukleides”, Philologus 45 (1885), 54–62; P. Riccardi, Saggio di una bibliografia Euclidea, Bologna 1887–1893; J. Hirschberg, “Die Optik der alten Griechen”, Zeitschrift für Psychologie und Physiologie der Sinnesorgane 16 (1898), 323–328; A. Lejeune, Euclide et Ptolémée, deux stades de l'optique géométrique grecque, Louvain 1948.
Notes: This translation of Euclid’s Optica from Greek to Latin was the most widely circulated of the medieval translations. The manuscript tradition of this version is exceedingly complicated, and immediately below I have listed 7 other variants having substantially the same incipit and enunciations, but differing significantly in the content and wording of the demonstrations (see Theisen for a discussion of some of these versions). Manuscripts whose designations in the above list are preceded by a dagger contain alternative enunciations for one or more of their propositions, drawn from De radits visualibus, the most popular Arabo-Latin translation of Euclid’s Optica (see 79C above). Finally, note that Heiberg was the first to publish the Latin text of De visu (or any other Latin version of Euclid’s Optica); earlier editions of Euclid’s optical works without exception substitute Theon’s recension of the Optica.

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 2)
Universal.Incipit: Ponatur lineas rectas ab oculo eductas ferri spatio ...” Prop. I: “Nullum visorum simul totum videtur. Habet alia translatio. In eodem instanti non videri plura. Exemplum sit B perpendicularis extensa ab oculo ...
Manuscript: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College Library, MS 504/271
Notes: For the first 34 props., this MS has alternative enunciations drawn from Euclid’s De radis visualibus
Manuscript.Catalogue: Montague Rhodes James, Supplement to the Catalogue of Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge 1914.

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 1)
Universal.Incipit: Ponatur ab oculo eductas rectas lineas ferri spatio ...” Prop. I: “Nullum visorum simul videtur totum. Esto autem : visum quidem AD oculus vero B a quo incidant visus BA BG BK BD ...
Manuscript: Cambridge, University Library, MS Mm.III.11
Edition1: Euclidis opera omnia, ed. Heiberg and Menge, vol. 7, pp. 3-121.
Edition2: W. R. Theisen, "The Medieval Tradition of Euclid's Optics", unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Wisconsin 1972, 66–271.
Edition3: H.E. Burton, “The Optics of Euclid”, Journal of the Optical Society of America 35 (1945), 357–372.
Literature: J. L. Heiberg, Litterargeschichtliche Studien über Euklid, Leipzig 1882, 90–148; H. Weissenborn, “Zur Optik des Eukleides”, Philologus 45 (1885), 54–62; P. Riccardi, Saggio di una bibliografia Euclidea, Bologna 1887–1893; J. Hirschberg, “Die Optik der alten Griechen”, Zeitschrift für Psychologie und Physiologie der Sinnesorgane 16 (1898), 323–328; A. Lejeune, Euclide et Ptolémée, deux stades de l'optique géométrique grecque, Louvain 1948.
Notes: This translation of Euclid’s Optica from Greek to Latin was the most widely circulated of the medieval translations. The manuscript tradition of this version is exceedingly complicated, and immediately below I have listed 7 other variants having substantially the same incipit and enunciations, but differing significantly in the content and wording of the demonstrations (see Theisen for a discussion of some of these versions). Manuscripts whose designations in the above list are preceded by a dagger contain alternative enunciations for one or more of their propositions, drawn from De radits visualibus, the most popular Arabo-Latin translation of Euclid’s Optica (see 79C above). Finally, note that Heiberg was the first to publish the Latin text of De visu (or any other Latin version of Euclid’s Optica); earlier editions of Euclid’s optical works without exception substitute Theon’s recension of the Optica.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Paul Binski and Patrick Zutshi, with collaboration of Stella Panayotova, Western Illuminated Manuscripts. A Catalogue of the Collection in Cambridge University Library, Cambridge 2011.

Universal.Incipit: “Visualis radius ab oculo super procedit lineas ...” Prop. I: “In eodem instant nulla videri plura. Cuius hec est ratio. Ponatur oculus super S cuius radius ad AB linee notas ADEUB progrediatur ...”
Manuscript: Firenze, Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale, MS Conv. soppr. J. I. 32
Edition1: W. R. Theisen, "The Medieval Tradition of Euclid's Optics", unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Wisconsin 1972, 403–422; see also 321–335.

Author: Euclid
Title: De speculis
Universal.Incipit: Visum rectum esse cuius media terminos ...
Manuscript: Firenze, Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale, MS Conv. soppr. J. I. 32
Edition1: There have been many Latin editions of Euclid’s Catroptrica, but I am not aware that any contain the medieval translation. The editions are listed by Pietro Riccardi, Saggio di una bibliografia Euclidea, 5 pts. (Bologna, 1887-1893), and by Ver Eecke, pp. xxxvi-xlvii. The latter : work contains a French translation of the Greek text.
Edition2: P. Ver Eecke, L'Optique et la Catoptrique. Avec une introduction et des notes, Brugge 1938, xxxvi–xlvii.
Literature: J. L. Heiberg, Litterargeschichtliche Studien über Euklid, Leipzig 1882, 148–153; Heiberg’s Prolegomena to Euclidis Opera omnia, ed. J. L. Heiberg and H. Menge, vol. 7 (Leipzig, 1895), xliii–lv; A. Lejeune, “Les ‘Postulats’ de la Catoptrique dite d’Euclide,” Archives internationales d’histoire des sciences 2 (1949), 598–613; A. Lejeune, Recherches sur la catoptrique grecque, Brussels 1957, 112–136.
Notes: The Greek work from which De speculis was translated is now generally agreed to be a late recension of a genuine Euclidean work, possibly edited by Theon of Alexandria. In some MSS it is attributed to Jordanus de Nemore. This De speculis must be distinguished from an Arabic compilation, also translated into Latin as Euclid’s De speculis; on the latter work, see Pseudo-Euclid (80), below.
Manuscript.Catalogue: A. A. Björnbo, Die mathematischen S. Marcohandschriften in Florenz, Quaderni di Storia e Critica della Scienza 8, Pisa 1976, 75-81

Universal.Incipit: Epongasi dal’occhio le menate dritte linee ...” Prop. I: “Nullo ciascuno tutto de vederi insieme si vede. Sara impero il vedere et AD I’occhio B al quale incitano li vederi BA BG BK BD...”
Manuscript: Firenze, Biblioteca Riccardiana, MS 2206 (I)
Notes: An Italian translation (from the Latin) of Euclid’s De visu, version 1 (79E, above).

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 6), edited by Witelo (?), fl. 1270.
Universal.Incipit: “Supponatur ab oculo eductas lineas rectas ferri spatio ..” Prop I: “Nullum visorum simul totum videtur. Alia translatio: In eodem instanti non videri plura. Esto visum AC oculus vero B dico ergo quod non simul comprehendetur a visu AD ...”
Manuscript: Firenze, Biblioteca Riccardiana, MS 885
Notes: Yet another version of Euclid’s De visu. Like that of Aimar, it has (nearly) the same incipit and enunciations as version 1, but the demonstrations contain very significant variations. The explicit of the Vatican MS assigns the work to Witelo, and Theisen has argued for Witelo’s editorship : on stylistic grounds as well. All six of these MSS contain alternative enunciations taken from Euclid’s De radiis visualibus (79C).

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 1)
Universal.Incipit: Ponatur ab oculo eductas rectas lineas ferri spatio ...” Prop. I: “Nullum visorum simul videtur totum. Esto autem : visum quidem AD oculus vero B a quo incidant visus BA BG BK BD ...
Manuscript: London, British Museum, MS Sloane 285
Edition1: Euclidis opera omnia, ed. Heiberg and Menge, vol. 7, pp. 3-121.
Edition2: W. R. Theisen, "The Medieval Tradition of Euclid's Optics", unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Wisconsin 1972, 66–271.
Edition3: H.E. Burton, “The Optics of Euclid”, Journal of the Optical Society of America 35 (1945), 357–372.
Literature: J. L. Heiberg, Litterargeschichtliche Studien über Euklid, Leipzig 1882, 90–148; H. Weissenborn, “Zur Optik des Eukleides”, Philologus 45 (1885), 54–62; P. Riccardi, Saggio di una bibliografia Euclidea, Bologna 1887–1893; J. Hirschberg, “Die Optik der alten Griechen”, Zeitschrift für Psychologie und Physiologie der Sinnesorgane 16 (1898), 323–328; A. Lejeune, Euclide et Ptolémée, deux stades de l'optique géométrique grecque, Louvain 1948.
Notes: This translation of Euclid’s Optica from Greek to Latin was the most widely circulated of the medieval translations. The manuscript tradition of this version is exceedingly complicated, and immediately below I have listed 7 other variants having substantially the same incipit and enunciations, but differing significantly in the content and wording of the demonstrations (see Theisen for a discussion of some of these versions). Manuscripts whose designations in the above list are preceded by a dagger contain alternative enunciations for one or more of their propositions, drawn from De radits visualibus, the most popular Arabo-Latin translation of Euclid’s Optica (see 79C above). Finally, note that Heiberg was the first to publish the Latin text of De visu (or any other Latin version of Euclid’s Optica); earlier editions of Euclid’s optical works without exception substitute Theon’s recension of the Optica.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Ayscough, S., A Catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the British Museum (1782) ?, ?. Catalogus Librorum MSS. Bibliothecae Sloanianae, London (Fahnen).

Author: Euclid
Title: De radiis visualibus (Liber de fallacia visus).
Universal.Incipit: “Visualis radius ab oculo super procedit lineas ...” Prop. I: “In eodem instant nulla videri plura. Cuius hec est ratio. Ponatur oculus super S cuius radius ad AB linee notas ADEUB progrediatur ...”
Manuscript: Madrid, Biblioteca Nacional de España, MS 9119
Edition1: W. R. Theisen, "The Medieval Tradition of Euclid's Optics", unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Wisconsin 1972, 403–422; see also 321–335.
Notes: Another translation of Euclid’s Optica from Arabic to Latin. The enunciations from this version are also inserted as glosses in certain MSS of the Greco-Latin translation of Euclid’s Optica; see 79E, 79F, 79G, 791, 79], below.
Manuscript.Catalogue: J. Domínguez Bordona, Catálogo de los manuscritos catalanes de la Biblioteca Nacional (Madrid 1931) 281 (= # 638)

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 6), edited by Witelo (?), fl. 1270.
Universal.Incipit: “Supponatur ab oculo eductas lineas rectas ferri spatio ..” Prop I: “Nullum visorum simul totum videtur. Alia translatio: In eodem instanti non videri plura. Esto visum AC oculus vero B dico ergo quod non simul comprehendetur a visu AD ...”
Manuscript: Milan, Biblioteca Ambrosiana, MS R.47 sup.
Notes: Yet another version of Euclid’s De visu. Like that of Aimar, it has (nearly) the same incipit and enunciations as version 1, but the demonstrations contain very significant variations. The explicit of the Vatican MS assigns the work to Witelo, and Theisen has argued for Witelo’s editorship : on stylistic grounds as well. All six of these MSS contain alternative enunciations taken from Euclid’s De radiis visualibus (79C).
Manuscript.Catalogue: Revelli # 330, Rivolta # 122, Gabriel (1968) 333-4

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 5), edited by Aimar (also entitled De linea visuali)
Universal.Incipit: “Ponatur ab oculo lineas rectas ferri spatio ...” Prop. I: “Nullum visorum simul videtur totum. In alia translatione habetur in eodem instanti non videri plura. Cuius hec est ratio. Sit visum B oculus A a quo incidant visus C D E F ad 4 diversas notulas ...”
Manuscript: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Corpus Christi College 283
Notes: Another version of Euclid’s De visu (the Greco-Latin translation of the Optica). It has the same incipit and enunciations as version 1 (79E, above), but in place of the usual demonstrations contains glosses or paraphrases attributed to a certain Aimar, who is not otherwise known. Both MSS conclude: “Nota quod sexaginta et tria toreumata continentur in isto libro. Age Aimare gratias Deo quod hoc opus sic glosulau sub magistro Johanne de Beaumont. Explicit benigniter.” Both MSS also include alternative enunciations taken from Euclid. De raditis visualibus (79C).
Manuscript.Catalogue: Thomson (2011), A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of Corpus Christi College Oxford, p. 147

Author: Euclid
Title: De radiis visualibus (Liber de fallacia visus).
Universal.Incipit: “Visualis radius ab oculo super procedit lineas ...” Prop. I: “In eodem instant nulla videri plura. Cuius hec est ratio. Ponatur oculus super S cuius radius ad AB linee notas ADEUB progrediatur ...”
Manuscript: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Digby 174
Edition1: W. R. Theisen, "The Medieval Tradition of Euclid's Optics", unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Wisconsin 1972, 403–422; see also 321–335.
Notes: Another translation of Euclid’s Optica from Arabic to Latin. The enunciations from this version are also inserted as glosses in certain MSS of the Greco-Latin translation of Euclid’s Optica; see 79E, 79F, 79G, 791, 79], below.
Manuscript.Catalogue: A catalogue of Western manuscripts at the Bodleian Libraries and selected Oxford colleges

Title: De aspectibus
Universal.Incipit: Radius egreditur ab oculo super lineas equales rectas. Prop. I: “Nullum visibilium totum videtur simul. Sit itaque linea AB id quod videtur. Dico ergo quod linea AB non est possibile ...
Manuscript: Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS Lat. 9335
Edition1: W. R. Theisen, "The Medieval Tradition of Euclid's Optics", unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Wisconsin 1972, 336–384; see also 321–335.

Author: Euclid
Title: De radiis visualibus (Liber de fallacia visus).
Universal.Incipit: “Visualis radius ab oculo super procedit lineas ...” Prop. I: “In eodem instant nulla videri plura. Cuius hec est ratio. Ponatur oculus super S cuius radius ad AB linee notas ADEUB progrediatur ...”
Manuscript: Seville, Biblioteca Colombina, MS 7.6.2
Edition1: W. R. Theisen, "The Medieval Tradition of Euclid's Optics", unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Wisconsin 1972, 403–422; see also 321–335.
Notes: Another translation of Euclid’s Optica from Arabic to Latin. The enunciations from this version are also inserted as glosses in certain MSS of the Greco-Latin translation of Euclid’s Optica; see 79E, 79F, 79G, 791, 79], below.
Manuscript.Catalogue: AL Catalogue, p. 829-830

Author: Euclid
Title: De speculis
Universal.Incipit: Visum rectum esse cuius media terminos ...
Manuscript: Seville, Biblioteca Colombina, MS 7.6.2
Edition1: There have been many Latin editions of Euclid’s Catroptrica, but I am not aware that any contain the medieval translation. The editions are listed by Pietro Riccardi, Saggio di una bibliografia Euclidea, 5 pts. (Bologna, 1887-1893), and by Ver Eecke, pp. xxxvi-xlvii. The latter : work contains a French translation of the Greek text.
Edition2: P. Ver Eecke, L'Optique et la Catoptrique. Avec une introduction et des notes, Brugge 1938, pp. xxxvi–xlvii.
Literature: J. L. Heiberg, Litterargeschichtliche Studien über Euklid, Leipzig 1882, 148–153; Heiberg’s Prolegomena to Euclidis Opera omnia, ed. J. L. Heiberg and H. Menge, vol. 7 (Leipzig, 1895), xliii–lv; A. Lejeune, “Les ‘Postulats’ de la Catoptrique dite d’Euclide,” Archives internationales d’histoire des sciences 2 (1949), 598–613; A. Lejeune, Recherches sur la catoptrique grecque, Brussels 1957, 112–136.
Notes: The Greek work from which De speculis was translated is now generally agreed to be a late recension of a genuine Euclidean work, possibly edited by Theon of Alexandria. In some MSS it is attributed to Jordanus de Nemore. This De speculis must be distinguished from an Arabic compilation, also translated into Latin as Euclid’s De speculis; on the latter work, see Pseudo-Euclid (80), below.
Manuscript.Catalogue: AL Catalogue, p. 829-830

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 5), edited by Aimar (also entitled De linea visuali)
Universal.Incipit: “Ponatur ab oculo lineas rectas ferri spatio ...” Prop. I: “Nullum visorum simul videtur totum. In alia translatione habetur in eodem instanti non videri plura. Cuius hec est ratio. Sit visum B oculus A a quo incidant visus C D E F ad 4 diversas notulas ...”
Manuscript: Seville, Biblioteca Colombina, MS 7.6.2
Notes: Another version of Euclid’s De visu (the Greco-Latin translation of the Optica). It has the same incipit and enunciations as version 1 (79E, above), but in place of the usual demonstrations contains glosses or paraphrases attributed to a certain Aimar, who is not otherwise known. Both MSS conclude: “Nota quod sexaginta et tria toreumata continentur in isto libro. Age Aimare gratias Deo quod hoc opus sic glosulau sub magistro Johanne de Beaumont. Explicit benigniter.” Both MSS also include alternative enunciations taken from Euclid. De raditis visualibus (79C).
Manuscript.Catalogue: AL Catalogue, p. 829-830

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 6), edited by Witelo (?), fl. 1270.
Universal.Incipit: “Supponatur ab oculo eductas lineas rectas ferri spatio ..” Prop I: “Nullum visorum simul totum videtur. Alia translatio: In eodem instanti non videri plura. Esto visum AC oculus vero B dico ergo quod non simul comprehendetur a visu AD ...”
Manuscript: Toruń , Książnica miejska im. Kopernika, MS Gymnasialbibl. R. 4°.2
Notes: Yet another version of Euclid’s De visu. Like that of Aimar, it has (nearly) the same incipit and enunciations as version 1, but the demonstrations contain very significant variations. The explicit of the Vatican MS assigns the work to Witelo, and Theisen has argued for Witelo’s editorship : on stylistic grounds as well. All six of these MSS contain alternative enunciations taken from Euclid’s De radiis visualibus (79C).

Author: Euclid
Title: De aspectuum diversitate (Theon of Alexandria’s Recension?)
Universal.Incipit: Supponatur aspectus qui ab oculo proveniunt secundum rectas ferri ...” Prop. I: “Nullum eorum quo aspiciuntur simul totum videri. Esto itaque quidpiam aspectum AD et sit oculus B a quo incidant aspectus BA BC BK BD ...
Manuscript: Vatican, Biblioteca Apostolica, MS Urb. Lat. 1329
Edition1: W. R. Theisen, "The Medieval Tradition of Euclid's Optics", unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Wisconsin 1972, 324.
Notes: Despite the absence of the preface by which Theon’s recension of Euclid’s Optica is usually identified, Theisen has argued that this is in fact Theon’s version. The many printed editions of the Latin translation of Theon's recension do not contain this particular version.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Digital Vatican Library, Manuscripts List

Author: Euclid
Title: De visu (version 1)
Universal.Incipit: Ponatur ab oculo eductas rectas lineas ferri spatio ...” Prop. I: “Nullum visorum simul videtur totum. Esto autem : visum quidem AD oculus vero B a quo incidant visus BA BG BK BD ...
Manuscript: Vatican, Biblioteca Apostolica, MS Vat. Lat. 2975
Edition1: Euclidis opera omnia, ed. Heiberg and Menge, vol. 7, pp. 3-121.
Edition2: W. R. Theisen, "The Medieval Tradition of Euclid's Optics", unpublished doctoral dissertation, University of Wisconsin 1972, 66–271.
Edition3: H.E. Burton, “The Optics of Euclid”, Journal of the Optical Society of America 35 (1945), 357–372.
Literature: J. L. Heiberg, Litterargeschichtliche Studien über Euklid, Leipzig 1882, 90–148; H. Weissenborn, “Zur Optik des Eukleides”, Philologus 45 (1885), 54–62; P. Riccardi, Saggio di una bibliografia Euclidea, Bologna 1887–1893; J. Hirschberg, “Die Optik der alten Griechen”, Zeitschrift für Psychologie und Physiologie der Sinnesorgane 16 (1898), 323–328; A. Lejeune, Euclide et Ptolémée, deux stades de l'optique géométrique grecque, Louvain 1948.
Notes: This translation of Euclid’s Optica from Greek to Latin was the most widely circulated of the medieval translations. The manuscript tradition of this version is exceedingly complicated, and immediately below I have listed 7 other variants having substantially the same incipit and enunciations, but differing significantly in the content and wording of the demonstrations (see Theisen for a discussion of some of these versions). Manuscripts whose designations in the above list are preceded by a dagger contain alternative enunciations for one or more of their propositions, drawn from De radits visualibus, the most popular Arabo-Latin translation of Euclid’s Optica (see 79C above). Finally, note that Heiberg was the first to publish the Latin text of De visu (or any other Latin version of Euclid’s Optica); earlier editions of Euclid’s optical works without exception substitute Theon’s recension of the Optica.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Digital Vatican Library, Manuscripts List

Author: Fusoris, Johannes
Title: De constituendo speculorum (?)
Universal.Incipit: Speculum in quo visu uno multe apparebunt ymagines se moventes constituere ...
Manuscript: Dijon, Bibliothèque Municipale, MS 441 (266)
Notes: Anonymous in the MS, but follows Fusoris’ De sectione mukesi.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Catalogue général des manuscrits des bibliothèques publiques de France. Départements — Tome V. Dijon. Par MM. Molinier, Omont, Bougenot et Guignard. Paris, Plon-Nourrit, 1889

Author: Fusoris, Johannes
Title: De sectione mukesi
Universal.Incipit: Subtili indagatione reperierunt perspectivi geometre ...
Manuscript: Dijon, Bibliothèque Municipale, MS 441 (266)
Manuscript.Catalogue: Catalogue général des manuscrits des bibliothèques publiques de France. Départements — Tome V. Dijon. Par MM. Molinier, Omont, Bougenot et Guignard. Paris, Plon-Nourrit, 1889

Author: Galen of Pergamum
Title: Les letres que Galien trames a Coris de les malalties dels uyls, tr. Johannes Jacobi. (?)
Universal.Incipit: A questa es remembranga de les letres de Galien que trames a Coris ...
Manuscript: *Saragossa, Biblioteca Capitular de La Seo y del Pilar, MS 1265
Edition1: The full text is given in Lluis Deztany and Josep M. Simon de Guilleuma, eds., Alcoad, Libre de la Figura del uyl, text Catala traduit de l’Arab per Mestre Joan Jacme (Barcelona, 1933), 220–236. This Catalan text has been rendered into Latin by Pansier, Collectio Ophthalmologica Veterum Auctorum, fasc. 7 (Paris, 1933), 213–221.
Notes: A Catalan translation, by Johannes Jacobi (Joan Jacme), of a work that Pansier regards as an Arabic compilation based on Galen.

Author: Galen of Pergamum
Title: De anatomia oculorum
Universal.Incipit: Quia oportet secundum amacionem (!) distentie (!) et utilitatem artis ...
Manuscript: Vatican, Biblioteca Apostolica, MS Palat. Lat. 1211
Edition1: Galen, Opera (Venice, 1490), vol. 1, fol. 161r-v; (;
Edition2: Galen, Opera (Pavia, 1515), vol. 1, fols. 50v-51r
Edition3: other early editions.
Literature: L. Thorndike, “Translations of Works of Galen from the Greek by Niccolo da Reggio”, Byzantina Metabyzantina 1 (1946–1949), 220.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Ludwig Schuba, Die medizinischen Handschriften der Codices Palatini Latini in der Vatikanischen Bibliothek (Kataloge der Universitätsbibliothek Heidelberg I), Wiesbaden 1981, 201.

Author: Gentile da Foligno
Title: Consilia et recepte ad egritudines oculorum et ad debilitatem visus
Universal.Incipit: Imaginationes iste suspicionem inducunt aque et quamvis...

Author: Gerard of Odo
Title: Questio de lumine
Universal.Incipit: Queritur utrum lumen augeatur per adventum nove partis...
Manuscript: Vatican, Biblioteca Apostolica, MS Vat. Lat. 3066
Notes: John Murdoch informs me that this is from Bk. I of Gerard’s Commentary on the Sentences, of which MSS are pleutiful.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Digital Vatican Library, Manuscripts List

Author: Giovanni da Fontana
Title: De speculo ardenti
Universal.Incipit: Dicta atque notata per me Johannem Fontana physicum Venetum et probata. Pro declaratione speculi ardentis quedam sunt principia declaranda ...

Notes: A brief commentary on Alhazen’s De speculis comburentibus

Author: Grassus, Benvenutus (of Jerusalem)
Title: Las curas de las enfermetatz et totas malautias dels ueths
Universal.Incipit: Senhors auiatz medescinas prov(a)das et esperiencias de las curas dels uels ...
Manuscript: Basel, Universitätsbibliothek, MS D. II. 11
Edition1: Le compendil pour la douleur et maladie des yeulx qui a esté ordonné par Bienvenu Graffe maistre et docteur en médecine. Edition francaise d’aprés le manuscrit de la Bibliothéque Nationale de Paris ... Suivie de la version provencale d’apreés le manuscrit de Bale, ed. P. Pansier, Ch. Laborde, and Henri Teulié (Paris, 1901).
Notes: A Provencal version of De egritudinibus oculorum.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Martin Steinmann, Die Handschriften der Universitätsbibliothek Basel, Register zu den Abteilungen C I - C VI, D - F sowie zu weiteren mittelalterlichen Handschriften und Fragmenten, Basel 1998.

Author: Grassus, Benvenutus (of Jerusalem)
Title: On Diseases of the Eyes (Of Human Eyes)
Universal.Incipit: A grete phylosopher and a profunde phycycyane clepid Benvonutius Grapheus after the sentence ...
Manuscript: Glasgow, University Library, MS Hunter 503
Edition1: An abridged English version of De egritudinibus oculorum is printed in Hippocrates, The whole aphorismes of great Hippocrates ... Whereunto ts annexed a short discourse of the nature and substance of the eye ... (London, 1610); however, I am uncertain whether it contains the same text found in the MSS.
Notes: The MSS contain an English translation or paraphrase of Benvenutus’ De egritudinibus oculorum. 1 have been unable to locate the Ashmolean fragment in the Glasgow MS, and therefore I cannot confirm that the two MSS represent the same translation or paraphrase.

Author: Grassus, Benvenutus (of Jerusalem)
Title: On Diseases of the Eyes (Of Human Eyes)
Universal.Incipit: So we did nedille it after ye manner of a gulyng ...
Manuscript: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 1468
Edition1: An abridged English version of De egritudinibus oculorum is printed in Hippocrates, The whole aphorismes of great Hippocrates ... Whereunto ts annexed a short discourse of the nature and substance of the eye ... (London, 1610); however, I am uncertain whether it contains the same text found in the MSS.
Notes: The MSS contain an English translation or paraphrase of Benvenutus’ De egritudinibus oculorum. 1 have been unable to locate the Ashmolean fragment in the Glasgow MS, and therefore I cannot confirm that the two MSS represent the same translation or paraphrase.
Manuscript.Catalogue: A catalogue of Western manuscripts at the Bodleian Libraries and selected Oxford colleges

Author: Grassus, Benvenutus (of Jerusalem)
Title: Compendil pour la douleur et maladie des yeulx
Universal.Incipit: Cy apres sensuit le compendil qui a este ordonne par Bien venu Raffe ... En considerant par nostre redempteur et souverain seigneur ...
Manuscript: Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS Franc. 1327
Edition1: Le compendil pour la douleur et maladie des yeulx qui a esté ordonné par Bienvenu Graffe maistre et docteur en médecine. Edition francaise d’aprés le manuscrit de la Bibliothéque Nationale de Paris ... Suivie de la version provencale d’apreés le manuscrit de Bale, ed. P. Pansier, Ch. Laborde, and Henri Teulié (Paris, 1901).
Notes: A French version of De egritudinibus oculorum.

Author: Hero of Alexandria

Author: John of Legnano
Title: De arbore consanguinitati
Universal.Incipit: Arbor bona facit fructus bonos ...” Part II (on optics) begins “Certior est cognitio que fit per oculum ...

Literature: J. P. McCall, "The Writings of John of Legnano with a List of Manuscripts”, Traditio 23 (1967), 415–437.
Notes: The second part of the treatise is entirely optical. The other MSS listed by McCall contain only part I of the treatise and hence no optics.

Author: Leonardo da Vinci
Title: Miscellaneous Optical Notes and Drawings
Universal.Incipit: Manuscripts (optical notes and drawings are scattered throughout Leonardo’s manuscripts, but the following manuscript codices contain particularly numerous or significant leaves devoted to optics)
Manuscript: Milan, Biblioteca Ambrosiana, Codex Atlanticus
Edition1: Il Codice Atlantico di Leonardo da Vinci nella Biblioteca Ambrosiana di Milano (Milan, 1894-1904).
Edition2: Les manuscrits de Léonard de Vinci, ed. Charles Ravaisson-Mollien, 6 vols. (Paris, 1881-1891)
Edition3: N. Ferrero, “Leonardo da Vinci: Of the Eye. An Original New Translation from Codex D", American Journal of Ophthamology, Ser. 3, vol. 35 (1952), 507–521.
Edition4: D. S. Strong, “Leonardo da Vinci on the Eye: The MS D in the Bibliothéque de l'Institut de France, Paris, Translated into English and Annotated with a Study of Leonardo’s Theories of Optics,” unpublished doctoral dissertation (UCLA, 1967).
Edition5: J. P. Richter, The Literary Works of Leonardo da Vinci, end ed., vol. 1 (London, 1939).
Edition6: E. MacCurdy, The Notebooks of Leonardo da Vinci, vol. 1 (New York, 1942).
Edition7: Scritti scelti di Leonardo da Vinci, ed. Anna Maria Brizio (Turin, 1952)
Edition8: Le prospettive e le ombre nelle opere di Leonardo da Vinci, ed. Amedeo Agostini (Pisa, 1954).
Literature: On Leonardo’s MSS, see Kate T. Steinitz, Manuscripts of Leonardo da Vinci.Their History, with a Description of the Manuscript Editions in Facsimile (Los Angeles, 1948). The best work on Leonardo’s optics is Strong’s dissertation (cited above); see also W. Elsdsser, “Die Funktion des Auges bei Leonardo da Vinci,” Zeitschrift fiir Mathematik und Physik, historisch-literarische Abteilung 45 (1900), 1–6; O. Werner, Zur Physik Leonardo da Vincis, Erlangen 1910; D. Argentieri, “L’ottica di Leonardo,” in Leonardo da Vinci, Milan 1940, 405–436 (translated into English, New York, 1956); M. H. Author: Maurolico, Francesco
Title: Photismi de lumine et umbra
Universal.Incipit: Lucidorum aliud quidem per se radiat ut sol flamma
Manuscript: Lucca, Biblioteca Governativa, MS 2080
Edition1: Photismi de lumine et umbra ad perspectivam et radiorum incedentiam facientes (Naples, 1611), pp. 1-99. English translation by Crew, Photismi de lumine, pp. 5-45.
Edition2: H. Crew, The Photismi de lumine of Maurolycus. A Chapter in Late Medieval Optics (New York, 1940), 5–45.
Literature: E. Wilde, Geschichte der Optik, vol. 1, Berlin 1838, 126–134: V. Ronchi, Stora della luce, 2nd ed., Bologna 1952, 92–106 (French trans. by J. Taton [Paris, 1956], 90–105: English trans. by V. Barocas {London, 1970], pp. 99–108): E. Rosen, “The Title of Maurolico’s Photismi", American Journal of Physics 94 (1957), 226–228: E. Rosen, “The Editions of Maurolico’s Mathematical Works”, Scripta Mathematica 24 (1989), 65–68; S. M. Straker, “Kepler’s Optics: A Study in the Development of Seventeenth-Century Natural Philosophy”, unpublished doctoral dissertation, Indiana University 1970, 292–300, 448–450.
Notes: This and the preceding two works of Maurolico have generally been treated as though together they comprise the Photismi de lumine et umbra; in fact, they are treated, both in the MSS and in the 1611 ed., as distinct treatisen. There is no ed. of Venice, 1575, nor of Messina, 1618, as commonly maintained.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Kristeller, P.O.: Iter Italicum I. London/Leiden : E.J. Brill. 1977., 261

Author: Palmerio da Cingoli, Jacopo
Title: Liber de passionibus oculorum
Universal.Incipit: Auditores circumstantes audiant omnes qui cupiunt audire novam scientiam et habere famam et virtutem ...
Manuscript: *Fusignano, Biblioteca comunale Carlo Piancastelli
Note: Formerly Rome, Lib. of Prince Baldassarre Boncompagni, MS 507.
Edition1: G. Albertotti, “Il libro delle affezioni oculari di Jacopo Palmerio da Cingoli ed altri scritti di oculistica tratti da un codice del secolo XV di Marco Sinzanogio da Sarnano,’ Memorie della Regia Accademia (Modena), Ser. 3, vol. 6 (1906), 3–85.
Literature: G. Albertotti, "Il libro delle affezioni oculari di Jacopo Palmerio da Cingoli ed altri scritti di oculistica tratti da un codice del secolo XV di Marco Sinzanogio da Sarnano", Memorie della Regia Accademia di scienze, lettere ed arti in Modena 3, 6 (1906), 3–85; N. Scalinci, “Liber pro sanitate oculorum’’ di M.° Davide Armenio oculista salernitano del secolo XII (Noto come ‘Tractatus de oculis Canamosali’), Naples 1934, 68–76.
Notes: Closely follows De egritudinibus oculorum of Benvenutus Grassus, as the similarity of incipits might suggest. This MS was written by Marco Sinzanogio, a medical student at Perugia.

Author: Peter of Limoges
Title: De oculo morali
Universal.Incipit: Si diligenter voluerimus in lege domini meditari ...
Manuscript: *Lincoln, Cathedral Library, MS 202 (3.2.)
Edition1: Tractatus Johannis Pithsani archiepiscopi Cantuariensis de oculo morali [Augsburg, 1475?]
Edition2: Liber de oculo morali editus ab eximio sacrarum litterarum professore magistro P. Lacepiera (Venice, 1496)
Edition3: De oculo mystico Raymundi Iordani (Lyon, 1641)
Edition4: De oculo morali Ioannis Gualensis, ed. Lucas Wadding (Viterbo, 1655)
Edition5: Opera omnia Raymundi Iordani Idiotae (Paris, 1654)
Edition6: Libro del occhio morale et spirituale vulgare, tr. Teofilo Romano (Venice, 1496).
Literature: H. Spettman, O. F. M., “Das Schriftchen De oculo morali’ und sein Verfasser”, Archivum Franciscanum Historicum 16 (1923), 309–322; J. Th. Welter, L’Exemplum dans la littérature religieuse et didactique du moyen age, Paris 1927, 177–180; P. Glorieux, Répertoire des maitres en théologie de Paris au XIII siécle, vol. 1, Paris 1938, 364–365: S.H. Thomson, The Writings of Robert Grosseteste, Bishop of Lincoln, 1235–1253, Cambridge 1940, 256–257.
Notes: Although much of this treatise is devoted to drawing moral and spiritual lessons from the science of optics, a significant core of optical knowledge and commentary is also present, and I have therefore deemed it appropriate to include the work in this bibliography. However, MSS are so numerous (and in any case have been adequately catalogued by others) that I have listed only those few that I have not found in these other bibliographies. For lists of MSS (numbering well over 100), see Spettman, Glorieux, Welter, and Thomson. This work has been attributed to Robert Grosse teste, John Pecham, Duns Scotus, Raymond Jordanus, and Johannes Gallensis.

Author: Petrus Hispanus
Alternative.Name: Pope John XXI
Title: De morbis oculorum (De passionibus oculorum/De egritudinibus oculorum/ De pattentibus oculis/ Liber de oculo/Secretum/ Aqua mirabilis/De aquis oculorum/Tractatus mirabilis aquarum/De aquis mirabilibus/Breviartum
Universal.Incipit: In nomine summi pontficis vel opificis a quo omnes cause procedunt ... Aqua mirabilis ad visum conservandum (conferendum) et contra omnem maculam ...
Manuscript: Basel, Universitätsbibliothek, MS D. II. 17
Edition1: A. M. Berger, ed., Die Ophthalmologie (liber de oculo) des Petrus Hispanus (Munich, 1899), accompanied by a German translation.
Literature: A. M. Berger, Die Ophtalmologie (liber de oculo) des Petrus Hispanus, Munich 1899; J. B. Petella, “Les connaissances oculistiques d’un médecin philosophe devenu pape”, Janus 2 (1897–1898), 405–420, 570–596; J. Hirschberg, "Geschichte der Augenheilkunde im Mittelalter und in der Neuzeit", in T. Saemisch (ed.), Graefe-Saemisch Handbuch der gesamten Augenheilkunde, 2nd ed., vol. 13, Leipzig 1908, 256–257; P. Pansier, Collectio Ophthalmologica Veterum Auctorum, fasc. 6, Paris 1908, 108–109; G. Sarton, Introduction to the History of Science, vol. 2, Baltimore 1931, 889–892.
Notes: Some MSS subdivide De morbis oculorum into two or three distinct treatises. The first of them begins with any of the first four incipits. The second, which also had a wide independent circulation as Aqua mirabilis or Tractatus mirabilis aquarum (or some similar title), begins with one of incipits (5) through (13). The third, when present, begins with incipit (14) or (15). An additional MS copy in Metz (Bibl. Munic., MS 379) was destroyed during World War II still other MS copies mentioned by Berger and others do not in fact contain De morbis oculorum.
Manuscript.Catalogue: M. Steinmann, Die Handschriften der Universitätsbibliothek Basel, Register zu den Abteilungen C I - C VI, D - F sowie zu weiteren mittelalterlichen Handschriften und Fragmenten, Basel 1998.

Author: Petrus Hispanus
Alternative.Name: Pope John XXI
Title: De morbis oculorum (De passionibus oculorum/De egritudinibus oculorum/ De pattentibus oculis/ Liber de oculo/Secretum/ Aqua mirabilis/De aquis oculorum/Tractatus mirabilis aquarum/De aquis mirabilibus/Breviartum
Universal.Incipit: In nomine summi pontficis vel opificis a quo omnes cause procedunt ... Tractatus mirabilis aquarum (aquarum mirabilis) quem composuit magister Petrus Yspanus (Hispanus) ex naturali industria ... Oculi patiuntur quandoque ex simplici materia quandoque ...
Manuscript: Basel, Universitätsbibliothek, MS D. III. 10
Edition1: A. M. Berger, ed., Die Ophthalmologie (liber de oculo) des Petrus Hispanus (Munich, 1899), accompanied by a German translation.

Author: Petrus Hispanus
Alternative.Name: Pope John XXI
Title: Libro degli occhi
Universal.Incipit: In nome di Dio amen. Comincia il trattato di maestro Piero di Spagna ... Occhi é uno membro nobile ritondo raggioso ...
Manuscript: Firenze, Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana, MS Redi 88 (186)
Edition1: F. Zambrini, ed., Volgarizzamento del Trattato della cura degli occhi di Pietro Spano, codice Laurenziano citato dagli Accademici della Crusca (Scelta di curtosita letterarie inedite o rare dal secolo XIII al XVII, vol. 130) (Bologna, 1873)
Edition2: A. M. Berger, ed., Der von Michel Angelo Buonarotti eigenhandig geschriebene Augen tractat (XVI. Jahrhundert) (Munich, 1897), pp. 14-19.
Notes: An Italian translation of Petrus’ De morbis oculorum. There is a lacuna in the Florence MS (and Zambrini’s edition based upon it), which is filled by the Vatican fragment (written in Michelangelo Buonarotti’s hand).
Manuscript.Catalogue: Fondo Ashburnham Catalogo

Author: Petrus Hispanus
Alternative.Name: Pope John XXI
Title: Libro degli occhi
Universal.Incipit: In nome di Dio amen. Comincia il trattato di maestro Piero di Spagna ... Occhi é uno membro nobile ritondo raggioso ...
Manuscript: Vatican, Biblioteca Apostolica, MS Vat. Lat. 3211
Note: Fragment beginning “Item arrossore ardore dolore e plurito dochi. Recipe aloe patico ...”
Edition1: F. Zambrini, ed., Volgarizzamento del Trattato della cura degli occhi di Pietro Spano, codice Laurenziano citato dagli Accademici della Crusca (Scelta di curtosita letterarie inedite o rare dal secolo XIII al XVII, vol. 130) (Bologna, 1873).
Edition2: A. M. Berger, ed., Der von Michel Angelo Buonarotti eigenhandig geschriebene Augen tractat (XVI. Jahrhundert) (Munich, 1897), pp. 14-19.
Notes: An Italian translation of Petrus’ De morbis oculorum. There is a lacuna in the Florence MS (and Zambrini’s edition based upon it), which is filled by the Vatican fragment (written in Michelangelo Buonarotti’s hand).
Manuscript.Catalogue: Digital Vatican Library, Manuscripts List

Author: Petrus Hispanus
Alternative.Name: Pope John XXI
Title: De morbis oculorum (De passionibus oculorum/De egritudinibus oculorum/ De pattentibus oculis/ Liber de oculo/Secretum/ Aqua mirabilis/De aquis oculorum/Tractatus mirabilis aquarum/De aquis mirabilibus/Breviartum
Universal.Incipit: Et feniculi rute verbene eufragie...
Manuscript: Vatican, Biblioteca Apostolica, MS Vat. Lat. 5377
Edition1: A. M. Berger, ed., Die Ophthalmologie (liber de oculo) des Petrus Hispanus (Munich, 1899), accompanied by a German translation.
Literature: A. M. Berger, Die Ophtalmologie (liber de oculo) des Petrus Hispanus, Munich 1899; J. B. Petella, “Les connaissances oculistiques d’un médecin philosophe devenu pape”, Janus 2 (1897–1898), 405–420, 570–596; J. Hirschberg, "Geschichte der Augenheilkunde im Mittelalter und in der Neuzeit", in T. Saemisch (ed.), Graefe-Saemisch Handbuch der gesamten Augenheilkunde, 2nd ed., vol. 13, Leipzig 1908, 256–257; P. Pansier, Collectio Ophthalmologica Veterum Auctorum, fasc. 6, Paris 1908, 108–109; G. Sarton, Introduction to the History of Science, vol. 2, Baltimore 1931, 889–892.
Notes: Some MSS subdivide De morbis oculorum into two or three distinct treatises. The first of them begins with any of the first four incipits. The second, which also had a wide independent circulation as Aqua mirabilis or Tractatus mirabilis aquarum (or some similar title), begins with one of incipits (5) through (13). The third, when present, begins with incipit (14) or (15). An additional MS copy in Metz (Bibl. Munic., MS 379) was destroyed during World War II still other MS copies mentioned by Berger and others do not in fact contain De morbis oculorum.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Digital Vatican Library, Manuscripts List

Petella, “Les connaissances oculistiques d’un médecin philosophe devenu pape”, Janus 2 (1897–1898), 405–420, 570–596; J. Hirschberg, "Geschichte der Augenheilkunde im Mittelalter und in der Neuzeit", in T. Saemisch (ed.), Graefe-Saemisch Handbuch der gesamten Augenheilkunde, 2nd ed., vol. 13, Leipzig 1908, 256–257; P. Pansier, Collectio Ophthalmologica Veterum Auctorum, fasc. 6, Paris 1908, 108–109; G. Sarton, Introduction to the History of Science, vol. 2, Baltimore 1931, 889–892.

Author: Pseudo-Euclid
Title: De speculis (Compositio speculorum mirabilium)
Universal.Incipit: Preparatio speculi in quo videas alterius imaginem ...
Manuscript: Basel, Universitätsbibliothek, MS F. II. 33
Edition1: A. A. Björnbo - S. Vogl, “Alkindi, Tideus und Pseudo-Euklid. Drei optische Werke”, Abhandlungen zur Geschichte der mathematischen Wissenschaften 26, 3 (1912), 95–119; MSS described, 123–147.
Literature: S. Vogl, “Uber die (Pseudo-)Euklidische Schrift ‘De speculis", Archiv für die Geschichte der Naturwissenschaften und der Technik 1 (1909), 419–435; D. C. Lindberg, “The Theory of Pinhole Images from Antiquity to the Thirteenth Century”, Archive for History of Exact Sciences 6, 4 (1970), 159–162.
Notes: This is an Arabic compilation of optical propositions and must be distinguished from Euclid’s Catoptrica (recension of Theon of Alexandria?), which also circulated in Latin as Euclid’s De speculis (79D, above).
Manuscript.Catalogue: Martin Steinmann, Die Handschriften der Universitätsbibliothek Basel, Register zu den Abteilungen C I - C VI, D - F sowie zu weiteren mittelalterlichen Handschriften und Fragmenten, Basel 1998.

Author: Soverus, Bartholomeus
Title: De refractione
Universal.Incipit: De loco imaginis. Antequam ad lumen imaginis demonstrandum ...
Manuscript: Venice, Biblioteca Nazionale Marciana, MS Lat. VIII.6 (Valentinelli X1.66)
Literature: A. Favaro, “Intorno alla vita ed alle opere di Bartolomeo Sovero matematico svizzero del secolo XVII”, Bullettino 15 (1882), 40–42.
Notes: A thorough discussion of refraction, in which Alhazen, Witelo, Kepler, and Aguilon are cited. A short discussion of refraction by Soverus is also contained in MS VIII. 8 (fols 5r-7r) of the same collection, there part of Soverus’ Geometrica, physica, et astronomica.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Kristeller, P. O.: Iter Italicum II, S.227; Valentinelli, Joseph: Bibliotheca Manuscripta ad S. Marci Venetiarum, Codices MSS. Latini, Tom. IV, Venedig, 1871, S.251f. (=Classis XI, Cod.66);

Author: Tideus
Title: De speculis (De speculis comburentibus/ De aspectibus/ De qualitate eius quod videtur in speculo)
Universal.Incipit: Scias (equidem) quod illud quod videt homo in speculo terso ...
Manuscript: Basel, Universitätsbibliothek, MS F. II. 33
Edition1: A. A. Björnbo - S. Vogl, “Alkindi, Tideus und Pseudo-Euklid. Drei optische Werke”, Abhandlungen zur Geschichte der mathematischen Wissenschaften 26, 3 (1912), 71–94; MSS described, 123-147.
Notes: The MSS identify Tideus as the son of the physician Theodorus. He has commonly been identified with the Greek mathematician Diocles (2nd century BC.), who wrote a book on burning mirrors, but without any justification.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Martin Steinmann, Die Handschriften der Universitätsbibliothek Basel, Register zu den Abteilungen C I - C VI, D - F sowie zu weiteren mittelalterlichen Handschriften und Fragmenten, Basel 1998.

Manuscript: München, Bayerische Staatsbibliothek, MS CLM 527
Edition1: A. A. Björnbo - S. Vogl, “Alkindi, Tideus und Pseudo-Euklid. Drei optische Werke”, Abhandlungen zur Geschichte der mathematischen Wissenschaften 26, 3 (1912), 71–94; MSS described, 123-147.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Karl Halm u.a., Catalogus codicum latinorum Bibliothecae Regiae Monacensis, Bd. I,1: Codices num. 1-2329 complectens (Catalogus codicum manu scriptorum Bibliothecae Regiae Monacensis III,1), München 1892, 149

Author: Tideus
Title: De speculis (De speculis comburentibus/ De aspectibus/ De qualitate eius quod videtur in speculo)
Universal.Incipit: Scias (equidem) quod illud quod videt homo in speculo terso ...
Manuscript: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Digby 168
Edition1: A. A. Björnbo - S. Vogl, “Alkindi, Tideus und Pseudo-Euklid. Drei optische Werke”, Abhandlungen zur Geschichte der mathematischen Wissenschaften 26, 3 (1912), 71–94; MSS described, 123-147.
Notes: The MSS identify Tideus as the son of the physician Theodorus. He has commonly been identified with the Greek mathematician Diocles (2nd century BC.), who wrote a book on burning mirrors, but without any justification.
Manuscript.Catalogue: A catalogue of Western manuscripts at the Bodleian Libraries and selected Oxford colleges

Author: Zacharias (of Salerno?)
Title: De passionibus oculorum (Sistlacera/ Sysalarac)
Universal.Incipit: Apud Paleon (Polion/Pollenarum/Paloen) artis nostre tractatores (tractatorem/tractatio res/tractatum res) pauca quidem ...
Manuscript: Basel, Universitätsbibliothek, MS D. III. 1
Edition1: F. A. Krah, Ein Münchener handschriftliches Augentraktat, betitelt “‘Liber sulse ractini, id est Secreta secretorum” (Leipzig, 1897) (from the Munich MS);
Edition2: P. Pansier, Collectio Ophthalmologica Veterum Auctorum, fasc. 5, Paris 1907, 59–92 (primarily from Paris MS 6988).
Literature: P. Pansier, Collectio ophtalmologica veterum auctorum, fasc. 5, Paris 1907, 59–92; J. Hirschberg, "Geschichte der Augenheilkunde im Mittelalter und in der Neuzeit", in T. Saemisch (ed.), Graefe-Saemisch Handbuch der gesamten Augenheilkunde, 2nd ed., vol. 13, Leipzig 1908, 255–256; N. Scalinci, “L’oculista medioevale M° Zaccaria e le fonti della sua ‘Sisilacera’", Rivista di storia delle scienze mediche e naturali 22 (1931), 8–21.
Notes: Many of the MSS attribute this treatise to Theophilus and some give Gerard of Cremona as its translator from Arabic to Latin; it appears, however, to have been compiled in Latin by a Magister Zacharias who probably studied at Salerno late in the 12th century. Pansier suggests that paloen or paleon derives from a Greek word meaning “the ancients” or another word meaning “many” (op. at., p. 77). I would propose, however, that Zacharias is here referring to Polemon (or Palemon) of Laodicea, who had dealt with the eye in his Physiognomonia.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Martin Steinmann, Die Handschriften der Universitätsbibliothek Basel, Register zu den Abteilungen C I - C VI, D - F sowie zu weiteren mittelalterlichen Handschriften und Fragmenten, Basel 1998.

Notes: Many of the MSS attribute this treatise to Theophilus and some give Gerard of Cremona as its translator from Arabic to Latin; it appears, however, to have been compiled in Latin by a Magister Zacharias who probably studied at Salerno late in the 12th century. Pansier suggests that paloen or paleon derives from a Greek word meaning “the ancients” or another word meaning “many” (op. at., p. 77). I would propose, however, that Zacharias is here referring to Polemon (or Palemon) of Laodicea, who had dealt with the eye in his Physiognomonia.
Manuscript.Catalogue: Ayscough, S., A Catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the British Museum (1782) 610, 615, 611.
